TernaryTree trimToSize	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ntrimToSize\npublic void trimToSize()\nEach node stores a character (splitchar) which is part of\n some key(s). In a compressed branch (one that only contain\n a single string key) the trailer of the key which is not\n already in nodes is stored  externally in the kv array.\n As items are inserted, key substrings decrease.\n Some substrings may completely  disappear when the whole\n branch is totally decompressed.\n The tree is traversed to find the key substrings actually\n used. In addition, duplicate substrings are removed using\n a map (implemented with a TernaryTree!).\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html
TernaryTree	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Ternary Search Tree.\nA ternary search tree is a hibrid between a binary tree and\n a digital search tree (trie). Keys are limited to strings.\n A data value of type char is stored in each leaf node.\n It can be used as an index (or pointer) to the data.\n Branches that only contain one key are compressed to one node\n by storing a pointer to the trailer substring of the key.\n This class is intended to serve as base class or helper class\n to implement Dictionary collections or the like. Ternary trees\n have some nice properties as the following: the tree can be\n traversed in sorted order, partial matches (wildcard) can be\n implemented, retrieval of all keys within a given distance\n from the target, etc. The storage requirements are higher than\n a binary tree but a lot less than a trie. Performance is\n comparable with a hash table, sometimes it outperforms a hash\n function (most of the time can determine a miss faster than a hash).\nThe main purpose of this java port is to serve as a base for\n implementing TeX's hyphenation algorithm (see The TeXBook,\n appendix H). Each language requires from 5000 to 15000 hyphenation\n patterns which will be keys in this tree. The strings patterns\n are usually small (from 2 to 5 characters), but each char in the\n tree is stored in a node. Thus memory usage is the main concern.\n We will sacrify 'elegance' to keep memory requirements to the\n minimum. Using java's char type as pointer (yes, I know pointer\n it is a forbidden word in java) we can keep the size of the node\n to be just 8 bytes (3 pointers and the data char). This gives\n room for about 65000 nodes. In my tests the english patterns\n took 7694 nodes and the german patterns 10055 nodes,\n so I think we are safe.\nAll said, this is a map with strings as keys and char as value.\n Pretty limited!. It can be extended to a general map by\n using the string representation of an object and using the\n char value as an index to an array that contains the object\n values.\nThis work was authored by Carlos Villegas (cav@uniscope.co.jp).</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TernaryTree.html

TextRenderer layout	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nlayout\npublic LayoutResult layout(LayoutContext layoutContext)\nDescription copied from interface: IRenderer\nThis method simulates positioning of the renderer, including all of its children, and returns\n the LayoutResult, representing the layout result, including occupied area, status, i.e.\n if there was enough place to fit the renderer subtree, etc.\n LayoutResult can be extended to return custom layout results for custom elements, e.g.\n TextRenderer uses TextLayoutResult as its result.\n\n This method can be called standalone to learn how much area the renderer subtree needs, or can be called\n before IRenderer.draw(DrawContext), to prepare the renderer to be flushed to the output stream.\n\nParameters:\nlayoutContext - the description of layout area and any other additional information\nReturns:\nresult of the layout process\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TextRenderer.html

TIFFDirectory TIFFDirectory	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nTIFFDirectory\npublic TIFFDirectory(RandomAccessFileOrArray stream,\n                     int directory)\n              throws IOException\nConstructs a TIFFDirectory from a SeekableStream.\n The directory parameter specifies which directory to read from\n the linked list present in the stream; directory 0 is normally\n read but it is possible to store multiple images in a single\n TIFF file by maintaining multiple directories.\n\nParameters:\nstream - a SeekableStream to read from.\ndirectory - the index of the directory to read.\nThrows:\nIOException\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFDirectory.html

TIFFDirectory getFieldAsByte	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetFieldAsByte\npublic byte getFieldAsByte(int tag,\n                           int index)\nReturns the value of a particular index of a given tag as a\n byte.  The caller is responsible for ensuring that the tag is\n present and has type TIFFField.TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_BYTE, or\n TIFF_UNDEFINED.\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFDirectory.html

The caller is responsible for ensuring that the tag is\n present and has type TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_UNDEFINED,\n TIFF_SHORT, TIFF_SSHORT, TIFF_SLONG or TIFF_LONG.\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFDirectory.html

TIFFDirectory getIFDOffset	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetIFDOffset\npublic long getIFDOffset()\nReturns the offset of the IFD corresponding to this\n TIFFDirectory.\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFDirectory.html
TIFFDirectory	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A class representing an Image File Directory (IFD) from a TIFF 6.0\n stream.  The TIFF file format is described in more detail in the\n comments for the TIFFDescriptor class.\n \n A TIFF IFD consists of a set of TIFFField tags.  Methods are\n provided to query the set of tags and to obtain the raw field\n array.  In addition, convenience methods are provided for acquiring\n the values of tags that contain a single value that fits into a\n byte, int, long, float, or double.\n \n Every TIFF file is made up of one or more public IFDs that are\n joined in a linked list, rooted in the file header.  A file may\n also contain so-called private IFDs that are referenced from\n tag data and do not appear in the main list.\n \n This class is not a committed part of the JAI API.  It may\n be removed or changed in future releases of JAI.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFDirectory.html

TIFFField getAsInt	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetAsInt\npublic int getAsInt(int index)\nReturns data in TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_UNDEFINED, TIFF_SHORT,\n TIFF_SSHORT, or TIFF_SLONG format as an int.\n\n  TIFF_BYTE and TIFF_UNDEFINED data are treated as unsigned;\n that is, no sign extension will take place and the returned\n value will be in the range [0, 255].  TIFF_SBYTE data will\n be returned in the range [-128, 127].\n\n  A ClassCastException will be thrown if the field is not of\n type TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_UNDEFINED, TIFF_SHORT,\n TIFF_SSHORT, or TIFF_SLONG.\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html
TIFFField getAsLong	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetAsLong\npublic long getAsLong(int index)\nReturns data in TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_UNDEFINED, TIFF_SHORT,\n TIFF_SSHORT, TIFF_SLONG, or TIFF_LONG format as a long.\n\n  TIFF_BYTE and TIFF_UNDEFINED data are treated as unsigned;\n that is, no sign extension will take place and the returned\n value will be in the range [0, 255].  TIFF_SBYTE data will\n be returned in the range [-128, 127].\n\n  A ClassCastException will be thrown if the field is not of\n type TIFF_BYTE, TIFF_SBYTE, TIFF_UNDEFINED, TIFF_SHORT,\n TIFF_SSHORT, TIFF_SLONG, or TIFF_LONG.\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html
TIFFField getAsFloat	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetAsFloat\npublic float getAsFloat(int index)\nReturns data in any numerical format as a float.  Data in\n TIFF_SRATIONAL or TIFF_RATIONAL format are evaluated by\n dividing the numerator into the denominator using\n double-precision arithmetic and then truncating to single\n precision.  Data in TIFF_SLONG, TIFF_LONG, or TIFF_DOUBLE\n format may suffer from truncation.\n\n  A ClassCastException will be thrown if the field is\n of type TIFF_UNDEFINED or TIFF_ASCII.\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html

TIFFField	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>A class representing a field in a TIFF 6.0 Image File Directory.\n\n  The TIFF file format is described in more detail in the\n comments for the TIFFDescriptor class.\n\n  A field in a TIFF Image File Directory (IFD).  A field is defined\n as a sequence of values of identical data type.  TIFF 6.0 defines\n 12 data types, which are mapped internally onto the Java data types\n byte, int, long, float, and double.\n\n  This class is not a committed part of the JAI API.  It may\n be removed or changed in future releases of JAI.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/TIFFField.html

The\n normalization rules:\n \n The primary subtag is lower case, the suggested practice of ISO 639.\n  All 2 letter secondary subtags are upper case, the suggested\n practice of ISO 3166.\n  All other subtags are lower case.\n \n\nParameters:\nvalue - raw value\nReturns:\nReturns the normalized value.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/Utils.html

Vector	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Represents a vector (i.e. a point in space).  This class is completely\n unrelated to the Vector class in the standard JRE.\n \n For many PDF related operations, the z coordinate is specified as 1\n This is to support the coordinate transformation calculations. XMPDateTime getCalendar	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetCalendar\nCalendar getCalendar()\n\nReturns:\nReturns a Calendar (only with milli second precision). \nNote: the dates before Oct 15th 1585 (which normally fall into validity of \n                the Julian calendar) are also rendered internally as Gregorian dates.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTime.html
XMPDateTime	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMPDateTime-class represents a point in time up to a resolution of nano\n seconds. Dates and time in the serialized XMP are ISO 8601 strings. There are utility functions\n to convert to the ISO format, a Calendar or get the Timezone. The fields of\n XMPDateTime are:\n \n month - The month in the range 1..12.\n  day - The day of the month in the range 1..31.\n  minute - The minute in the range 0..59.\n  hour - The time zone hour in the range 0..23.\n  minute - The time zone minute in the range 0..59.\n  nanoSecond - The nano seconds within a second. Note: if the XMPDateTime is\n converted into a calendar, the resolution is reduced to milli seconds.\n  timeZone - a TimeZone-object.\n \n DateTime values are occasionally used in cases with only a date or only a time component. A date\n without a time has zeros for all the time fields. A time without a date has zeros for all date\n fields (year, month, and day).</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTime.html
XMPDateTimeFactory createFromCalendar	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ncreateFromCalendar\npublic static XMPDateTime createFromCalendar(Calendar calendar)\nCreates an XMPDateTime from a Calendar-object.\n\nParameters:\ncalendar - a Calendar-object.\nReturns:\nAn XMPDateTime-object.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTimeFactory.html
XMPDateTimeFactory create	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ncreate\npublic static XMPDateTime create()\nCreates an empty XMPDateTime-object.\n\nReturns:\nReturns an XMPDateTime-object.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTimeFactory.html
XMPDateTimeFactory create	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ncreate\npublic static XMPDateTime create(int year,\n                                 int month,\n                                 int day)\nCreates an XMPDateTime-object from initial values.\n\nParameters:\nyear - years\nmonth - months from 1 to 12\nNote: Remember that the month in Calendar is defined from 0 to 11.\nday - days\nReturns:\nReturns an XMPDateTime-object.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTimeFactory.html
XMPDateTimeFactory create	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ncreate\npublic static XMPDateTime create(int year,\n                                 int month,\n                                 int day,\n                                 int hour,\n                                 int minute,\n                                 int second,\n                                 int nanoSecond)\nCreates an XMPDateTime-object from initial values.\n\nParameters:\nyear - years\nmonth - months from 1 to 12\nNote: Remember that the month in Calendar is defined from 0 to 11.\nday - days\nhour - hours\nminute - minutes\nsecond - seconds\nnanoSecond - nanoseconds\nReturns:\nReturns an XMPDateTime-object.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTimeFactory.html
XMPDateTimeFactory createFromISO8601	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ncreateFromISO8601\npublic static XMPDateTime createFromISO8601(String strValue)\n                                     throws XMPException\nCreates an XMPDateTime from an ISO 8601 string.\n\nParameters:\nstrValue - The ISO 8601 string representation of the date/time.\nReturns:\nAn XMPDateTime-object.\nThrows:\nXMPException - When the ISO 8601 string is non-conform\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTimeFactory.html
XMPDateTimeFactory getCurrentDateTime	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetCurrentDateTime\npublic static XMPDateTime getCurrentDateTime()\nObtain the current date and time.\n\nReturns:\nReturns The returned time is UTC, properly adjusted for the local time zone. The\n         resolution of the time is not guaranteed to be finer than seconds.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTimeFactory.html
XMPDateTimeFactory setLocalTimeZone	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetLocalTimeZone\npublic static XMPDateTime setLocalTimeZone(XMPDateTime dateTime)\nSets the local time zone without touching any other Any existing time zone value is replaced,\n the other date/time fields are not adjusted in any way.\n\nParameters:\ndateTime - the XMPDateTime variable containing the value to be modified.\nReturns:\nReturns an updated XMPDateTime-object.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTimeFactory.html
XMPDateTimeFactory convertToUTCTime	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nconvertToUTCTime\npublic static XMPDateTime convertToUTCTime(XMPDateTime dateTime)\nMake sure a time is UTC. If the time zone is not UTC, the time is\n adjusted and the time zone set to be UTC.\n\nParameters:\ndateTime - the XMPDateTime variable containing the time to\n            be modified.\nReturns:\nReturns an updated XMPDateTime-object.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPDateTimeFactory.html

XMPIterator skipSubtree	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nskipSubtree\nvoid skipSubtree()\nSkip the subtree below the current node when next() is\n called.\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIterator.html
XMPIterator	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>Interface for the XMPMeta iteration services.\n XMPIterator provides a uniform means to iterate over the\n schema and properties within an XMP object.\n \n The iteration over the schema and properties within an XMP object is very\n complex. It is helpful to have a thorough understanding of the XMP data tree.\n One way to learn this is to create some complex XMP and examine the output of\n XMPMeta#toString. This is also described in the XMP\n Specification, in the XMP Data Model chapter.\n \n The top of the XMP data tree is a single root node. This does not explicitly\n appear in the dump and is never visited by an iterator (that is, it is never\n returned from XMPIterator#next()). Beneath the root are\n schema nodes. These are just collectors for top level properties in the same\n namespace. They are created and destroyed implicitly. Beneath the schema\n nodes are the property nodes. The nodes below a property node depend on its\n type (simple, struct, or array) and whether it has qualifiers.\n \n An XMPIterator is created by XMPMeta#interator() constructor\n defines a starting point for the iteration and options that control how it\n proceeds. By default the iteration starts at the root and visits all nodes\n beneath it in a depth first manner. The root node is not visited, the first\n visited node is a schema node. You can provide a schema name or property path\n to select a different starting node. By default this visits the named root\n node first then all nodes beneath it in a depth first manner.\n \n The XMPIterator#next() method delivers the schema URI, path,\n and option flags for the node being visited. If the node is simple it also\n delivers the value. Qualifiers for this node are visited next. The fields of\n a struct or items of an array are visited after the qualifiers of the parent.\n \n The options to control the iteration are:\n \nJUST_CHILDREN - Visit just the immediate children of the root. Skip\n the root itself and all nodes below the immediate children. This omits the\n qualifiers of the immediate children, the qualifier nodes being below what\n they qualify, default is to visit the complete subtree.\n JUST_LEAFNODES - Visit just the leaf property nodes and their\n qualifiers.\n JUST_LEAFNAME - Return just the leaf component of the node names.\n The default is to return the full xmp path.\n OMIT_QUALIFIERS - Do not visit the qualifiers.\n INCLUDE_ALIASES - Adds known alias properties to the properties in the iteration.\n                Note: Not supported in Java XMPCore! \n \n\nnext() returns XMPPropertyInfo-objects and throws\n a NoSuchElementException if there are no more properties to\n return.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIterator.html
XMPIteratorImpl skipSiblings	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nskipSiblings\nprotected boolean skipSiblings\nflag to indicate that skipSiblings() has been called.\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIteratorImpl.html

XMPIteratorImpl getBaseNS	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetBaseNS\nprotected String getBaseNS()\n\nReturns:\nExposes the options for inner class.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIteratorImpl.html
XMPIteratorImpl	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>The XMPIterator implementation.\n Iterates the XMP Tree according to a set of options.\n During the iteration the XMPMeta-object must not be changed.\n Calls to skipSubtree() / skipSiblings() will affect the iteration.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPIteratorImpl.html
XMPMeta getProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetProperty\nXMPProperty getProperty(String schemaNS,\n                        String propName)\n                 throws XMPException\nThe property value getter-methods all take a property specification: the first two parameters\n are always the top level namespace URI (the "schema" namespace) and the basic name\n of the property being referenced. See the introductory discussion of path expression usage\n for more information.\n \n All of the functions return an object inherited from PropertyBase or\n null if the property does not exists. The result object contains the value of\n the property and option flags describing the property. Arrays and the non-leaf levels of\n nodes do not have values.\n \n See PropertyOptions for detailed information about the options.\n \n This is the simplest property getter, mainly for top level simple properties or after using\n the path composition functions in XMPPathFactory.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the property. May be null or the empty\n        string if the first component of the propName path contains a namespace prefix. The\n        URI must be for a registered namespace.\npropName - The name of the property. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Using a namespace prefix on the first\n        component is optional. If present without a schemaNS value then the prefix specifies\n        the namespace. The prefix must be for a registered namespace. If both a schemaNS URI\n        and propName prefix are present, they must be corresponding parts of a registered\n        namespace.\nReturns:\nReturns a XMPProperty containing the value and the options or\n         null if the property does not exist.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetArrayItem\nXMPProperty getArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                         String arrayName,\n                         int itemIndex)\n                  throws XMPException\nProvides access to items within an array. The index is passed as an integer, you need not\n worry about the path string syntax for array items, convert a loop index to a string, etc.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\narrayName - The name of the array. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\nitemIndex - The index of the desired item. Arrays in XMP are indexed from 1. The\n        constant XMPConst.ARRAY_LAST_ITEM always refers to the last existing array\n        item.\nReturns:\nReturns a XMPProperty containing the value and the options or\n         null if the property does not exist.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta countArrayItems	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ncountArrayItems\nint countArrayItems(String schemaNS,\n                    String arrayName)\n             throws XMPException\nReturns the number of items in the array.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\narrayName - The name of the array. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\nReturns:\nReturns the number of items in the array.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getStructField	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetStructField\nXMPProperty getStructField(String schemaNS,\n                           String structName,\n                           String fieldNS,\n                           String fieldName)\n                    throws XMPException\nProvides access to fields within a nested structure. The namespace for the field is passed as\n a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax.\n \n The names of fields should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML namespace. The path\n syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix. This is unreliable since the prefix is\n never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand in a given\n sequence of XML text.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the struct. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\nstructName - The name of the struct. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\nfieldNS - The namespace URI for the field. Has the same URI and prefix usage as the\n        schemaNS parameter.\nfieldName - The name of the field. Must be a single XML name, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as the\n        structName parameter.\nReturns:\nReturns a XMPProperty containing the value and the options or\n         null if the property does not exist. Arrays and non-leaf levels of\n         structs do not have values.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta getQualifier	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetQualifier\nXMPProperty getQualifier(String schemaNS,\n                         String propName,\n                         String qualNS,\n                         String qualName)\n                  throws XMPException\nProvides access to a qualifier attached to a property. The namespace for the qualifier is\n passed as a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax. In many regards qualifiers\n are like struct fields. See the introductory discussion of qualified properties for more\n information.\n \n The names of qualifiers should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML namespace. The\n path syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix. This is unreliable since the\n prefix is never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand\n in a given sequence of XML text.\n \nNote: Qualifiers are only supported for simple leaf properties at this time.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the struct. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\npropName - The name of the property to which the qualifier is attached. May be a general\n        path expression, must not be null or the empty string. Has the same\n        namespace prefix usage as in getProperty().\nqualNS - The namespace URI for the qualifier. Has the same URI and prefix usage as the\n        schemaNS parameter.\nqualName - The name of the qualifier. Must be a single XML name, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as the\n        propName parameter.\nReturns:\nReturns a XMPProperty containing the value and the options of the\n         qualifier or null if the property does not exist. The name of the\n         qualifier must be a single XML name, must not be null or the empty\n         string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as the propName parameter.\n         \n         The value of the qualifier is only set if it has one (Arrays and non-leaf levels of\n         structs do not have values).\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetProperty\nvoid setProperty(String schemaNS,\n                 String propName,\n                 Object propValue,\n                 PropertyOptions options)\n          throws XMPException\nThe property value setters all take a property specification, their\n differences are in the form of this. The first two parameters are always the top level\n namespace URI (the schema namespace) and the basic name of the property being\n referenced. See the introductory discussion of path expression usage for more information.\n \n All of the functions take a string value for the property and option flags describing the\n property. The value must be Unicode in UTF-8 encoding. Arrays and non-leaf levels of structs\n do not have values. Empty arrays and structs may be created using appropriate option flags.\n All levels of structs that is assigned implicitly are created if necessary. appendArayItem\n implicitly creates the named array if necessary.\n \n See PropertyOptions for detailed information about the options.\n \n This is the simplest property setter, mainly for top level simple properties or after using\n the path composition functions in XMPPathFactory.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the property. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\npropName - The name of the property.\n                                   Has the same usage as in getProperty().\npropValue - the value for the property (only leaf properties have a value).\n        Arrays and non-leaf levels of structs do not have values.\n        Must be null if the value is not relevant.\n        The value is automatically detected: Boolean, Integer, Long, Double, XMPDateTime and\n        byte[] are handled, on all other toString() is called.\noptions - Option flags describing the property. See the earlier description.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetProperty\nvoid setProperty(String schemaNS,\n                 String propName,\n                 Object propValue)\n          throws XMPException\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI\npropName - The name of the property\npropValue - the value for the property\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions\nSee Also:\nsetProperty(String, String, Object, PropertyOptions)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetArrayItem\nvoid setArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                  String arrayName,\n                  int itemIndex,\n                  String itemValue,\n                  PropertyOptions options)\n           throws XMPException\nReplaces an item within an array. The index is passed as an integer, you need not worry about\n the path string syntax for array items, convert a loop index to a string, etc. The array\n passed must already exist. In normal usage the selected array item is modified. A new item is\n automatically appended if the index is the array size plus 1.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\narrayName - The name of the array. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty.\nitemIndex - The index of the desired item. Arrays in XMP are indexed from 1. To address\n        the last existing item, use countArrayItems(String, String) to find\n        out the length of the array.\nitemValue - the new value of the array item. Has the same usage as propValue in\n        setProperty().\noptions - the set options for the item.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetArrayItem\nvoid setArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                  String arrayName,\n                  int itemIndex,\n                  String itemValue)\n           throws XMPException\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI\narrayName - The name of the array\nitemIndex - The index to insert the new item\nitemValue - the new value of the array item\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions\nSee Also:\nsetArrayItem(String, String, int, String, PropertyOptions)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta insertArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ninsertArrayItem\nvoid insertArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                     String arrayName,\n                     int itemIndex,\n                     String itemValue,\n                     PropertyOptions options)\n              throws XMPException\nInserts an item into an array previous to the given index. The index is passed as an integer,\n you need not worry about the path string syntax for array items, convert a loop index to a\n string, etc. The array passed must already exist. In normal usage the selected array item is\n modified. A new item is automatically appended if the index is the array size plus 1.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\narrayName - The name of the array. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty.\nitemIndex - The index to insert the new item. Arrays in XMP are indexed from 1. Use\n                  XMPConst.ARRAY_LAST_ITEM to append items.\nitemValue - the new value of the array item. Has the same usage as\n        propValue in setProperty().\noptions - the set options that decide about the kind of the node.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta insertArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ninsertArrayItem\nvoid insertArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                     String arrayName,\n                     int itemIndex,\n                     String itemValue)\n              throws XMPException\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array\narrayName - The name of the array\nitemIndex - The index to insert the new item\nitemValue - the value of the array item\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions\nSee Also:\ninsertArrayItem(String, String, int, String, PropertyOptions)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta appendArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nappendArrayItem\nvoid appendArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                     String arrayName,\n                     PropertyOptions arrayOptions,\n                     String itemValue,\n                     PropertyOptions itemOptions)\n              throws XMPException\nSimplifies the construction of an array by not requiring that you pre-create an empty array.\n The array that is assigned is created automatically if it does not yet exist. Each call to\n appendArrayItem() appends an item to the array. The corresponding parameters have the same\n use as setArrayItem(). The arrayOptions parameter is used to specify what kind of array. If\n the array exists, it must have the specified form.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\narrayName - The name of the array. May be a general path expression, must not be null or\n        the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as propPath in getProperty.\narrayOptions - Option flags describing the array form. The only valid options are\n        \n PropertyOptions.ARRAY,\n         PropertyOptions.ARRAY_ORDERED,\n         PropertyOptions.ARRAY_ALTERNATE or\n         PropertyOptions.ARRAY_ALT_TEXT.\n        \nNote: the array options only need to be provided if the array is not\n        already existing, otherwise you can set them to null or use\n        appendArrayItem(String, String, String).\nitemValue - the value of the array item. Has the same usage as propValue in getProperty.\nitemOptions - Option flags describing the item to append (PropertyOptions)\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta appendArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nappendArrayItem\nvoid appendArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                     String arrayName,\n                     String itemValue)\n              throws XMPException\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array\narrayName - The name of the array\nitemValue - the value of the array item\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions\nSee Also:\nappendArrayItem(String, String, PropertyOptions, String, PropertyOptions)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setStructField	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetStructField\nvoid setStructField(String schemaNS,\n                    String structName,\n                    String fieldNS,\n                    String fieldName,\n                    String fieldValue,\n                    PropertyOptions options)\n             throws XMPException\nProvides access to fields within a nested structure. The namespace for the field is passed as\n a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax. The names of fields should be XML\n qualified names, that is within an XML namespace. The path syntax for a qualified name uses\n the namespace prefix, which is unreliable because the prefix is never guaranteed. The URI is\n the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand in a given sequence of XML text.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the struct. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\nstructName - The name of the struct. May be a general path expression, must not be null\n        or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as propName in getProperty.\nfieldNS - The namespace URI for the field. Has the same URI and prefix usage as the\n        schemaNS parameter.\nfieldName - The name of the field. Must be a single XML name, must not be null or the\n        empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as the structName parameter.\nfieldValue - the value of thefield, if the field has a value.\n        Has the same usage as propValue in getProperty.\noptions - Option flags describing the field. See the earlier description.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setStructField	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetStructField\nvoid setStructField(String schemaNS,\n                    String structName,\n                    String fieldNS,\n                    String fieldName,\n                    String fieldValue)\n             throws XMPException\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the struct\nstructName - The name of the struct\nfieldNS - The namespace URI for the field\nfieldName - The name of the field\nfieldValue - the value of the field\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions\nSee Also:\nsetStructField(String, String, String, String, String, PropertyOptions)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setQualifier	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetQualifier\nvoid setQualifier(String schemaNS,\n                  String propName,\n                  String qualNS,\n                  String qualName,\n                  String qualValue,\n                  PropertyOptions options)\n           throws XMPException\nProvides access to a qualifier attached to a property. The namespace for the qualifier is\n passed as a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax. In many regards qualifiers\n are like struct fields. See the introductory discussion of qualified properties for more\n information. The names of qualifiers should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML\n namespace. The path syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix, which is\n unreliable because the prefix is never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is\n just a local shorthand in a given sequence of XML text. The property the qualifier\n will be attached has to exist.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the struct. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\npropName - The name of the property to which the qualifier is attached. Has the same\n        usage as in getProperty.\nqualNS - The namespace URI for the qualifier. Has the same URI and prefix usage as the\n        schemaNS parameter.\nqualName - The name of the qualifier. Must be a single XML name, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as the\n        propName parameter.\nqualValue - A pointer to the null terminated UTF-8 string that is the\n        value of the qualifier, if the qualifier has a value. Has the same usage as propValue\n        in getProperty.\noptions - Option flags describing the qualifier. See the earlier description.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

XMPMeta getLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetLocalizedText\nXMPProperty getLocalizedText(String schemaNS,\n                             String altTextName,\n                             String genericLang,\n                             String specificLang)\n                      throws XMPException\nThese functions provide convenient support for localized text properties, including a number\n of special and obscure aspects. Localized text properties are stored in alt-text arrays. They\n allow multiple concurrent localizations of a property value, for example a document title or\n copyright in several languages. The most important aspect of these functions is that they\n select an appropriate array item based on one or two RFC 3066 language tags. One of these\n languages, the "specific" language, is preferred and selected if there is an exact match. For\n many languages it is also possible to define a "generic" language that may be used if there\n is no specific language match. The generic language must be a valid RFC 3066 primary subtag,\n or the empty string. For example, a specific language of "en-US" should be used in the US,\n and a specific language of "en-UK" should be used in England. It is also appropriate to use\n "en" as the generic language in each case. If a US document goes to England, the "en-US"\n title is selected by using the "en" generic language and the "en-UK" specific language. It is\n considered poor practice, but allowed, to pass a specific language that is just an RFC 3066\n primary tag. For example "en" is not a good specific language, it should only be used as a\n generic language. Passing "i" or "x" as the generic language is also considered poor practice\n but allowed. Advice from the W3C about the use of RFC 3066 language tags can be found at:\n http://www.w3.org/International/articles/language-tags/\n \nNote: RFC 3066 language tags must be treated in a case insensitive manner. The XMP\n Toolkit does this by normalizing their capitalization:\n \n The primary subtag is lower case, the suggested practice of ISO 639.\n  All 2 letter secondary subtags are upper case, the suggested practice of ISO 3166.\n  All other subtags are lower case. The XMP specification defines an artificial language,\n "x-default", that is used to explicitly denote a default item in an alt-text array.\n \n The XMP toolkit normalizes alt-text arrays such that the x-default item is the first item.\n The SetLocalizedText function has several special features related to the x-default item, see\n its description for details. The selection of the array item is the same for GetLocalizedText\n and SetLocalizedText:\n \n Look for an exact match with the specific language.\n  If a generic language is given, look for a partial match.\n  Look for an x-default item.\n  Choose the first item.\n \n A partial match with the generic language is where the start of the item's language matches\n the generic string and the next character is '-'. An exact match is also recognized as a\n degenerate case. It is fine to pass x-default as the specific language. In this case,\n selection of an x-default item is an exact match by the first rule, not a selection by the\n 3rd rule. The last 2 rules are fallbacks used when the specific and generic languages fail to\n produce a match. getLocalizedText returns information about a selected item in\n an alt-text array. The array item is selected according to the rules given above.\n\n Note: In a future version of this API a method\n                using Java java.lang.Locale will be added.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the alt-text array. Has the same usage as in\n        getProperty().\naltTextName - The name of the alt-text array. May be a general path expression, must not\n        be null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\ngenericLang - The name of the generic language as an RFC 3066 primary subtag. May be\n        null or the empty string if no generic language is wanted.\nspecificLang - The name of the specific language as an RFC 3066 tag. Must not be\n        null or the empty string.\nReturns:\nReturns an XMPProperty containing the value, the actual language and\n                   the options if an appropriate alternate collection item exists, null\n                  if the property.\n         does not exist.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetLocalizedText\nvoid setLocalizedText(String schemaNS,\n                      String altTextName,\n                      String genericLang,\n                      String specificLang,\n                      String itemValue,\n                      PropertyOptions options)\n               throws XMPException\nModifies the value of a selected item in an alt-text array. Creates an appropriate array item\n if necessary, and handles special cases for the x-default item. If the selected item is from\n a match with the specific language, the value of that item is modified. If the existing value\n of that item matches the existing value of the x-default item, the x-default item is also\n modified. If the array only has 1 existing item (which is not x-default), an x-default item\n is added with the given value. If the selected item is from a match with the generic language\n and there are no other generic matches, the value of that item is modified. If the existing\n value of that item matches the existing value of the x-default item, the x-default item is\n also modified. If the array only has 1 existing item (which is not x-default), an x-default\n item is added with the given value. If the selected item is from a partial match with the\n generic language and there are other partial matches, a new item is created for the specific\n language. The x-default item is not modified. If the selected item is from the last 2 rules\n then a new item is created for the specific language. If the array only had an x-default\n item, the x-default item is also modified. If the array was empty, items are created for the\n specific language and x-default.\n\n Note: In a future version of this API a method\n                using Java java.lang.Locale will be added.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the alt-text array. Has the same usage as in\n        getProperty().\naltTextName - The name of the alt-text array. May be a general path expression, must not\n        be null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\ngenericLang - The name of the generic language as an RFC 3066 primary subtag. May be\n        null or the empty string if no generic language is wanted.\nspecificLang - The name of the specific language as an RFC 3066 tag. Must not be\n        null or the empty string.\nitemValue - A pointer to the null terminated UTF-8 string that is the new\n        value for the appropriate array item.\noptions - Option flags, none are defined at present.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta setLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetLocalizedText\nvoid setLocalizedText(String schemaNS,\n                      String altTextName,\n                      String genericLang,\n                      String specificLang,\n                      String itemValue)\n               throws XMPException\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the alt-text array\naltTextName - The name of the alt-text array\ngenericLang - The name of the generic language\nspecificLang - The name of the specific language\nitemValue - the new value for the appropriate array item\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions\nSee Also:\nsetLocalizedText(String, String, String, String, String, PropertyOptions)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

XMPMeta getPropertyBase64	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetPropertyBase64\nbyte[] getPropertyBase64(String schemaNS,\n                         String propName)\n                  throws XMPException\nConvenience method to retrieve the literal value of a property.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the property. XMPMeta iterator	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\niterator\nXMPIterator iterator(String schemaNS,\n                     String propName,\n                     IteratorOptions options)\n              throws XMPException\nConstruct an iterator for the properties within an XMP object. According to the parameters it iterates the entire data tree,\n properties within a specific schema, or a subtree rooted at a specific node.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - Optional schema namespace URI to restrict the iteration. Omitted (visit all\n        schema) by passing null or empty String.\npropName - Optional property name to restrict the iteration. May be an arbitrary path\n        expression. Omitted (visit all properties) by passing null or empty\n        String. If no schema URI is given, it is ignored.\noptions - Option flags to control the iteration. See IteratorOptions for\n        details.\nReturns:\nReturns an XMPIterator for this XMPMeta-object\n         considering the given options.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

XMPMeta getPacketHeader	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetPacketHeader\nString getPacketHeader()\n\nReturns:\nReturns the unparsed content of the <?xpacket> processing instruction.\n                This contains normally the attribute-like elements 'begin="<BOM>"\n                id="W5M0MpCehiHzreSzNTczkc9d"' and possibly the deprecated elements 'bytes="1234"' or\n                'encoding="XXX"'. XMPMeta sort	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsort\nvoid sort()\nSorts the complete datamodel according to the following rules:\n \nSchema nodes are sorted by prefix.\n                Properties at top level and within structs are sorted by full name, that is\n                        prefix + local name.\n                Array items are not sorted, even if they have no certain order such as bags.\n                Qualifier are sorted, with the exception of "xml:lang" and/or "rdf:type"\n                        that stay at the top of the list in that order.\n \n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta normalize	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nnormalize\nvoid normalize(ParseOptions options)\n        throws XMPException\nPerform the normalization as a separate parsing step.\n Normally it is done during parsing, unless the parsing option\n ParseOptions.OMIT_NORMALIZATION is set to true.\n Note: It does no harm to call this method to an already normalized xmp object.\n It was a PDF/A requirement to get hand on the unnormalized XMPMeta object.\n\nParameters:\noptions - optional parsing options.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html
XMPMeta	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>This class represents the set of XMP metadata as a DOM representation. It has methods to read and\n modify all kinds of properties, create an iterator over all properties and serialize the metadata\n to a String, byte-array or OutputStream.</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMeta.html

XMPMetaFactory parse	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nparse\npublic static XMPMeta parse(InputStream in,\n                            ParseOptions options)\n                     throws XMPException\nThese functions support parsing serialized RDF into an XMP object, and serailizing an XMP\n object into RDF. The input for parsing may be any valid Unicode\n encoding. ISO Latin-1 is also recognized, but its use is strongly discouraged. Serialization\n is always as UTF-8.\n \nparseFromBuffer() parses RDF from an InputStream. The encoding\n is recognized automatically.\n\nParameters:\nin - an InputStream\noptions - Options controlling the parsing.\n                The available options are:\n                \n XMP_REQUIRE_XMPMETA - The <x:xmpmeta> XML element is required around\n                <rdf:RDF>.\n                 XMP_STRICT_ALIASING - Do not reconcile alias differences, throw an exception.\n                \nNote:The XMP_STRICT_ALIASING option is not yet implemented.\nReturns:\nReturns the XMPMeta-object created from the input.\nThrows:\nXMPException - If the file is not well-formed XML or if the parsing fails.\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaFactory.html

XMPMetaImpl appendArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nappendArrayItem\npublic void appendArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                            String arrayName,\n                            PropertyOptions arrayOptions,\n                            String itemValue,\n                            PropertyOptions itemOptions)\n                     throws XMPException\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nSimplifies the construction of an array by not requiring that you pre-create an empty array.\n The array that is assigned is created automatically if it does not yet exist. Each call to\n appendArrayItem() appends an item to the array. The corresponding parameters have the same\n use as setArrayItem(). The arrayOptions parameter is used to specify what kind of array. If\n the array exists, it must have the specified form.\n\nSpecified by:\nappendArrayItem in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\narrayName - The name of the array. May be a general path expression, must not be null or\n        the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as propPath in getProperty.\narrayOptions - Option flags describing the array form. The only valid options are\n        \n PropertyOptions.ARRAY,\n         PropertyOptions.ARRAY_ORDERED,\n         PropertyOptions.ARRAY_ALTERNATE or\n         PropertyOptions.ARRAY_ALT_TEXT.\n        \nNote: the array options only need to be provided if the array is not\n        already existing, otherwise you can set them to null or use\n        XMPMeta.appendArrayItem(String, String, String).\nitemValue - the value of the array item. Has the same usage as propValue in getProperty.\nitemOptions - Option flags describing the item to append (PropertyOptions)\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.appendArrayItem(String, String, PropertyOptions, String,\n      PropertyOptions)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl appendArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nappendArrayItem\npublic void appendArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                            String arrayName,\n                            String itemValue)\n                     throws XMPException\n\nSpecified by:\nappendArrayItem in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array\narrayName - The name of the array\nitemValue - the value of the array item\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.appendArrayItem(String, String, String)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html

XMPMetaImpl deleteArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ndeleteArrayItem\npublic void deleteArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                            String arrayName,\n                            int itemIndex)\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nDeletes the given XMP subtree rooted at the given array item. It is not an error if the array\n item does not exist.\n\nSpecified by:\ndeleteArrayItem in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\narrayName - The name of the array. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\nitemIndex - The index of the desired item. Arrays in XMP are indexed from 1. The\n        constant XMPConst.ARRAY_LAST_ITEM always refers to the last\n        existing array item.\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.deleteArrayItem(String, String, int)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl deleteProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ndeleteProperty\npublic void deleteProperty(String schemaNS,\n                           String propName)\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nDeletes the given XMP subtree rooted at the given property. It is not an error if the\n property does not exist.\n\nSpecified by:\ndeleteProperty in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the property. Has the same usage as in\n        getProperty().\npropName - The name of the property. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.deleteProperty(String, String)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl deleteQualifier	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ndeleteQualifier\npublic void deleteQualifier(String schemaNS,\n                            String propName,\n                            String qualNS,\n                            String qualName)\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nDeletes the given XMP subtree rooted at the given qualifier. It is not an error if the\n qualifier does not exist.\n\nSpecified by:\ndeleteQualifier in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the struct. XMPMetaImpl getArrayItem	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetArrayItem\npublic XMPProperty getArrayItem(String schemaNS,\n                                String arrayName,\n                                int itemIndex)\n                         throws XMPException\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nProvides access to items within an array. The index is passed as an integer, you need not\n worry about the path string syntax for array items, convert a loop index to a string, etc.\n\nSpecified by:\ngetArrayItem in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the array. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\narrayName - The name of the array. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\nitemIndex - The index of the desired item. Arrays in XMP are indexed from 1. The\n        constant XMPConst.ARRAY_LAST_ITEM always refers to the last existing array\n        item.\nReturns:\nReturns a XMPProperty containing the value and the options or\n         null if the property does not exist.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.getArrayItem(String, String, int)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl getLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetLocalizedText\npublic XMPProperty getLocalizedText(String schemaNS,\n                                    String altTextName,\n                                    String genericLang,\n                                    String specificLang)\n                             throws XMPException\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nThese functions provide convenient support for localized text properties, including a number\n of special and obscure aspects. Localized text properties are stored in alt-text arrays. They\n allow multiple concurrent localizations of a property value, for example a document title or\n copyright in several languages. The most important aspect of these functions is that they\n select an appropriate array item based on one or two RFC 3066 language tags. One of these\n languages, the "specific" language, is preferred and selected if there is an exact match. For\n many languages it is also possible to define a "generic" language that may be used if there\n is no specific language match. The generic language must be a valid RFC 3066 primary subtag,\n or the empty string. For example, a specific language of "en-US" should be used in the US,\n and a specific language of "en-UK" should be used in England. It is also appropriate to use\n "en" as the generic language in each case. If a US document goes to England, the "en-US"\n title is selected by using the "en" generic language and the "en-UK" specific language. It is\n considered poor practice, but allowed, to pass a specific language that is just an RFC 3066\n primary tag. For example "en" is not a good specific language, it should only be used as a\n generic language. Passing "i" or "x" as the generic language is also considered poor practice\n but allowed. Advice from the W3C about the use of RFC 3066 language tags can be found at:\n http://www.w3.org/International/articles/language-tags/\n \nNote: RFC 3066 language tags must be treated in a case insensitive manner. The XMP\n Toolkit does this by normalizing their capitalization:\n \n The primary subtag is lower case, the suggested practice of ISO 639.\n  All 2 letter secondary subtags are upper case, the suggested practice of ISO 3166.\n  All other subtags are lower case. The XMP specification defines an artificial language,\n "x-default", that is used to explicitly denote a default item in an alt-text array.\n \n The XMP toolkit normalizes alt-text arrays such that the x-default item is the first item.\n The SetLocalizedText function has several special features related to the x-default item, see\n its description for details. The selection of the array item is the same for GetLocalizedText\n and SetLocalizedText:\n \n Look for an exact match with the specific language.\n  If a generic language is given, look for a partial match.\n  Look for an x-default item.\n  Choose the first item.\n \n A partial match with the generic language is where the start of the item's language matches\n the generic string and the next character is '-'. An exact match is also recognized as a\n degenerate case. It is fine to pass x-default as the specific language. In this case,\n selection of an x-default item is an exact match by the first rule, not a selection by the\n 3rd rule. The last 2 rules are fallbacks used when the specific and generic languages fail to\n produce a match. getLocalizedText returns information about a selected item in\n an alt-text array. The array item is selected according to the rules given above.\n\n Note: In a future version of this API a method\n                using Java java.lang.Locale will be added.\n\nSpecified by:\ngetLocalizedText in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the alt-text array. Has the same usage as in\n        getProperty().\naltTextName - The name of the alt-text array. May be a general path expression, must not\n        be null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\ngenericLang - The name of the generic language as an RFC 3066 primary subtag. May be\n        null or the empty string if no generic language is wanted.\nspecificLang - The name of the specific language as an RFC 3066 tag. Must not be\n        null or the empty string.\nReturns:\nReturns an XMPProperty containing the value, the actual language and\n                   the options if an appropriate alternate collection item exists, null\n                  if the property.\n         does not exist.\nThrows:\nXMPException\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.getLocalizedText(String, String, String, String)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl setLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetLocalizedText\npublic void setLocalizedText(String schemaNS,\n                             String altTextName,\n                             String genericLang,\n                             String specificLang,\n                             String itemValue,\n                             PropertyOptions options)\n                      throws XMPException\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nModifies the value of a selected item in an alt-text array. Creates an appropriate array item\n if necessary, and handles special cases for the x-default item. If the selected item is from\n a match with the specific language, the value of that item is modified. If the existing value\n of that item matches the existing value of the x-default item, the x-default item is also\n modified. If the array only has 1 existing item (which is not x-default), an x-default item\n is added with the given value. If the selected item is from a match with the generic language\n and there are no other generic matches, the value of that item is modified. If the existing\n value of that item matches the existing value of the x-default item, the x-default item is\n also modified. If the array only has 1 existing item (which is not x-default), an x-default\n item is added with the given value. If the selected item is from a partial match with the\n generic language and there are other partial matches, a new item is created for the specific\n language. The x-default item is not modified. If the selected item is from the last 2 rules\n then a new item is created for the specific language. If the array only had an x-default\n item, the x-default item is also modified. If the array was empty, items are created for the\n specific language and x-default.\n\n Note: In a future version of this API a method\n                using Java java.lang.Locale will be added.\n\nSpecified by:\nsetLocalizedText in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the alt-text array. Has the same usage as in\n        getProperty().\naltTextName - The name of the alt-text array. May be a general path expression, must not\n        be null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\ngenericLang - The name of the generic language as an RFC 3066 primary subtag. May be\n        null or the empty string if no generic language is wanted.\nspecificLang - The name of the specific language as an RFC 3066 tag. Must not be\n        null or the empty string.\nitemValue - A pointer to the null terminated UTF-8 string that is the new\n        value for the appropriate array item.\noptions - Option flags, none are defined at present.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.setLocalizedText(String, String, String, String, String,\n      PropertyOptions)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl setLocalizedText	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\nsetLocalizedText\npublic void setLocalizedText(String schemaNS,\n                             String altTextName,\n                             String genericLang,\n                             String specificLang,\n                             String itemValue)\n                      throws XMPException\n\nSpecified by:\nsetLocalizedText in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the alt-text array\naltTextName - The name of the alt-text array\ngenericLang - The name of the generic language\nspecificLang - The name of the specific language\nitemValue - the new value for the appropriate array item\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.setLocalizedText(String, String, String, String, String)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl getProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetProperty\npublic XMPProperty getProperty(String schemaNS,\n                               String propName)\n                        throws XMPException\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nThe property value getter-methods all take a property specification: the first two parameters\n are always the top level namespace URI (the "schema" namespace) and the basic name\n of the property being referenced. See the introductory discussion of path expression usage\n for more information.\n \n All of the functions return an object inherited from PropertyBase or\n null if the property does not exists. The result object contains the value of\n the property and option flags describing the property. Arrays and the non-leaf levels of\n nodes do not have values.\n \n See PropertyOptions for detailed information about the options.\n \n This is the simplest property getter, mainly for top level simple properties or after using\n the path composition functions in XMPPathFactory.\n\nSpecified by:\ngetProperty in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the property. May be null or the empty\n        string if the first component of the propName path contains a namespace prefix. The\n        URI must be for a registered namespace.\npropName - The name of the property. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Using a namespace prefix on the first\n        component is optional. If present without a schemaNS value then the prefix specifies\n        the namespace. The prefix must be for a registered namespace. If both a schemaNS URI\n        and propName prefix are present, they must be corresponding parts of a registered\n        namespace.\nReturns:\nReturns a XMPProperty containing the value and the options or\n         null if the property does not exist.\nThrows:\nXMPException\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.getProperty(String, String)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl getProperty	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetProperty\nprotected XMPProperty getProperty(String schemaNS,\n                                  String propName,\n                                  int valueType)\n                           throws XMPException\nReturns a property, but the result value can be requested. It can be one\n of VALUE_STRING, VALUE_BOOLEAN,\n VALUE_INTEGER, VALUE_LONG,\n VALUE_DOUBLE, VALUE_DATE,\n VALUE_CALENDAR, VALUE_BASE64.\n\nParameters:\nschemaNS - a schema namespace\npropName - a property name or path\nvalueType - the type of the value, see VALUE_...\nReturns:\nReturns an XMPProperty\nThrows:\nXMPException - Collects any exception that occurs.\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.getProperty(String, String)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html

XMPMetaImpl getQualifier	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetQualifier\npublic XMPProperty getQualifier(String schemaNS,\n                                String propName,\n                                String qualNS,\n                                String qualName)\n                         throws XMPException\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nProvides access to a qualifier attached to a property. The namespace for the qualifier is\n passed as a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax. In many regards qualifiers\n are like struct fields. See the introductory discussion of qualified properties for more\n information.\n \n The names of qualifiers should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML namespace. The\n path syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix. This is unreliable since the\n prefix is never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand\n in a given sequence of XML text.\n \nNote: Qualifiers are only supported for simple leaf properties at this time.\n\nSpecified by:\ngetQualifier in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the struct. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\npropName - The name of the property to which the qualifier is attached. May be a general\n        path expression, must not be null or the empty string. Has the same\n        namespace prefix usage as in getProperty().\nqualNS - The namespace URI for the qualifier. Has the same URI and prefix usage as the\n        schemaNS parameter.\nqualName - The name of the qualifier. Must be a single XML name, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as the\n        propName parameter.\nReturns:\nReturns a XMPProperty containing the value and the options of the\n         qualifier or null if the property does not exist. The name of the\n         qualifier must be a single XML name, must not be null or the empty\n         string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as the propName parameter.\n         \n         The value of the qualifier is only set if it has one (Arrays and non-leaf levels of\n         structs do not have values).\nThrows:\nXMPException\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.getQualifier(String, String, String, String)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
XMPMetaImpl getStructField	A										<section class="prog__container"><p>\ngetStructField\npublic XMPProperty getStructField(String schemaNS,\n                                  String structName,\n                                  String fieldNS,\n                                  String fieldName)\n                           throws XMPException\nDescription copied from interface: XMPMeta\nProvides access to fields within a nested structure. The namespace for the field is passed as\n a URI, you need not worry about the path string syntax.\n \n The names of fields should be XML qualified names, that is within an XML namespace. The path\n syntax for a qualified name uses the namespace prefix. This is unreliable since the prefix is\n never guaranteed. The URI is the formal name, the prefix is just a local shorthand in a given\n sequence of XML text.\n\nSpecified by:\ngetStructField in interface XMPMeta\nParameters:\nschemaNS - The namespace URI for the struct. Has the same usage as in getProperty.\nstructName - The name of the struct. May be a general path expression, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as\n        propName in getProperty().\nfieldNS - The namespace URI for the field. Has the same URI and prefix usage as the\n        schemaNS parameter.\nfieldName - The name of the field. Must be a single XML name, must not be\n        null or the empty string. Has the same namespace prefix usage as the\n        structName parameter.\nReturns:\nReturns a XMPProperty containing the value and the options or\n         null if the property does not exist. Arrays and non-leaf levels of\n         structs do not have values.\nThrows:\nXMPException - Wraps all errors and exceptions that may occur.\nSee Also:\nXMPMeta.getStructField(String, String, String, String)\n\n</p></section>	http://itextsupport.com/apidocs/itext7/XMPMetaImpl.html
